contentrichtext.text: {{Taxobox | name = Paradise Parrot | status = EX | status_system = IUCN3.1 | status_ref = <ref name=iucn>{{IUCN2010.4 |assessors=BirdLife International |year=2008 |id=142510/0 |title=Psephotus pulcherrimus |downloaded= 17 April 2011}}</ref> | Critically Endangered = 2012 | image = Psephotus pulcherrimus.jpg | image_width = 250px | image_caption = Live specimen photographed by the entrance to its nest, Burnett River, Queensland, 1922 | regnum = [[Animal]]ia | phylum = [[Chordate|Chordata]] | classis = [[bird|Aves]] | ordo = [[Psittaciformes]] | superfamilia = [[Psittacoidea]] | familia = [[Psittaculidae]] | subfamilia = [[Platycercinae]] | tribus = [[Platycercini]] | genus = ''[[Psephotus]]'' | species = '''''P. pulcherrimus''''' | binomial = ''Psephotus pulcherrimus'' | binomial_authority = ([[John Gould|Gould]], 1845) }} The '''Paradise Parrot''' (''Psephotus pulcherrimus'') was a colourful medium-sized [[parrot]] native to the grassy woodlands of the [[Queensland]] - [[New South Wales]] border area of eastern [[Australia]]. Once moderately common within its fairly restricted range, the last live bird was seen in 1927. Extensive and sustained searches in the years since then have failed to produce any reliable evidence of it, and it is unknown if it is extinct or not. [[File:Psephotus pulcherrimus nest.jpg|thumb|left|Nest, 1922]] [[File:Paradise Parrot.jpg|thumb|left|upright|Painting from 1884]] [[File:Psephotus pulcherrimus by nest.jpg|upright|thumb|left|Two specimens by a nest, 1922]] Paradise Parrots lived in pairs or small family groups, making their nests in hollowed-out [[termite]] mounds and similar places, often at or near ground level, and feeding, so far as is known, almost exclusively on grass seeds. The plumage was extraordinarily colorful, even by parrot standards, a mixture of turquoise, aqua, scarlet, black and brown, and the tail almost the same length as the body—something difficult to understand in a bird that, although a rapid, undulating flyer, spent almost all of its time on the ground. The reasons for the sudden decline of the Paradise Parrot remain speculative. Possibilities include overgrazing, land clearing, changed fire regimes, hunting by bird collectors, and predation by [[Australian feral predators|introduced mammals]] like [[feral cat|cat]]s. It became rare towards the end of the 19th century and was thought extinct by 1915. A series of searches turned up a few more individuals over the next decade, but the last confirmed sighting was on 14 September 1927. {{clear}} ==References== {{reflist}} * ''Glimpses of Paradise: The Quest for the Beautiful Parakeet'', Penny Olsen ISBN 978-0-642-27652-0, Canberra: National Library of Australia, 2007 ==External links== *[http://nlbif.eti.uva.nl/naturalis/detail?lang=uk&id=47 3D view] of specimens RMNH 110.071, RMNH 110.072, RMNH 110.073, RMNH 110.074 and RMNH 110.113 at [[Naturalis]], Leiden (requires [[QuickTime]] browser plugin). {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} [[Category:Broad-tailed parrots]] [[Category:Extinct birds of Australia]] [[Category:Psephotus]] [[Category:Bird extinctions since 1500]] [[Category:Animals described in 1845]] [[Category:1927 in the environment]]
